description: From Middle English degre, borrowed from Old French degré (French: degré), itself from Latin gradus, with the prefix de-.

entries.meaning: A stage of proficiency or qualification in a course of study, now especially an award bestowed by a university or, in some countries, a college, as a certification of academic achievement. (In the United States, can include secondary schools.) [from 14th c.]
examples: She has two bachelor's degrees and is studying towards a master's degree.

entries.meaning: (geometry) A unit of measurement of angle equal to 1⁄360 of a circle's circumference. [from 14th c.]
examples: A right angle is a ninety-degree angle.
Most humans have a field of vision of almost 180 degrees.

entries.meaning: (physics) A unit of measurement of temperature on any of several scales, such as Celsius or Fahrenheit. [from 18th c.]
examples: 180 degrees Fahrenheit is equivalent to 100 degrees Celsius.

entries.meaning: (algebra) The sum of the exponents of a term; the order of a polynomial. [from 18th c.]
examples: A quadratic polynomial is a polynomial of degree 2.

entries.meaning: (algebra, field theory) The dimensionality of a field extension.
examples: The set of complex numbers constitutes a field extension of degree 2 over the real numbers.

The Galois field

entries.meaning: (graph theory) The number of edges that a vertex takes part in; a valency.
(logic) The number of logical connectives in a formula.
(surveying) The curvature of a circular arc, expressed as the angle subtended by a fixed length of arc or chord.
(geography) A unit of measurement of latitude and longitude which together identify a location on the Earth's surface.
(grammar) Any of the three stages (positive, comparative, superlative) in the comparison of an adjective or an adverb.
(obsolete outside heraldry) A step on a set of stairs; the rung of a ladder. [from 13th c.]
An individual step, or stage, in any process or scale of values. [from 13th c.]
A stage of rank or privilege; social standing. [from 13th c.]

examples: Louis created the École militaire in Paris in 1751, in which 500 scholarships were designated for noblemen able to prove four degrees of noble status.

entries.meaning: (now rare) One's relative state or experience; way, manner. [from 14th c.]
The amount that an entity possesses a certain property; relative intensity, extent. [from 14th c.]
examples: To what degree do the two accounts of the accident concur?
